results.title: The International Telecommunication Union
results.creator_credit: Krishna Singh, Ramakantha Sarma and United Nations. Office of Public Information
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The United Nations: Its Charter and Organization”.
The conquest of time and distance in communications is one of the miracles of the modern age. Records the technological advances and growing co-operation among nations from the early pioneers to the latest spacecommunication satellites. The role of the International Telecommunication Union is emphasised particularly in the developing countries.

results.title: The Economic and Social Council
results.creator_credit: Krishna Singh and United Nations. Office of Public Information
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The United Nations: Its Charter and Organization”.
Describes how the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations strives to promote international co-operation in fighting economic and social misery wherever it exists.

results.title: Beneath the frozen world
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau”.
The Jacques Cousteau team photograph underwater the life and iceforms of Antarctica, during its brief summer. Suitable for Upper Primary level students. No other credits available.

results.title: The Flight of penguins
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau”.
Jacques Cousteau looks at the penguin colonies of the Antarctic, describing the evolution of penguins from birds to marine animals, their mating habits and care of the young.

results.title: Whales
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau”.
Shows Jacques Costeau and his crew touring the sea in the last surviving wooden whaling boat, viewing an experiment with a whale at marine world in California and conducting a series of studies in the Indian Ocean.

results.title: Sunken treasure
results.creator_credit: Jacques Cousteau Productions and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau”.
Shows Jacques Cousteau and his crew exploring the site of a wreck believed to be the command ship of the 1641 New World Armada. Also shows the crew testing some new ideas about underwater archaeological salvaging techniques. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.description:
Episode of Series “The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau”.

results.title: The Night of the squid
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau”.
Sea Arrow Squids gather in large masses during their annual mating frenzy. The males transfer packets of sperm from their bodies to that of the female by using a specially adapted tentacle. The female attaches the fertilised egg clusters to the sea bottom where they hatch in approximately 28 days. Commentary by Rod Serling.

results.title: Return of the sea elephant
results.creator_credit: Jacques-Yves Cousteau, Churchill Films and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau”.
On the island of Guadalupe, 130 miles off the west coast of Mexico, there is a colony of unique aquatic mammals, the nosed sea elephants. On this trip, Cousteau and the crew of the Calypso examine the habits of these unusual animals and try to gather information as to the size of the herd, whether new colonies are forming and where they go in their seven months at sea. With Jacques Cousteau and narrated by Rod Serling.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jacques-Yves Cousteau, Churchill Films and Wolper Productions

results.title: The Unsinkable sea otter
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau”.
This shy sea mammal is fighting its way back to an ecological niche after two centuries of being hunted for its fur. But again the otter is under threat, both from abalone divers (who say it is destroying their supply) and from pollution of the coastal waters off Alaska and California. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
